document.text: Winchester.Mrs. Isabelle Burwell Mayo, 72 years old, wife of Peter H. Mayo, the millionaire tobacco mer chant of Richmond, was stricken with paralysis and died at Powhatan, their Clarke county estate near Millwood. Her remains were interred in the graveyard at Old Chapel, near Mill- wood, Sunday afternoon. She was a daughter of the late George H. Bur- well and was born in the mansion on the noted Carter Hall estate. In addi tion to her husband, she leaves fwo daughters, Mrs. Thomas N. Carter, of Richmond, Va., and Mrs. Bennehan Cameron, of Raleigh, N. C. two sis ters, Mrs. T. H. V. Randolph and Mrs. R. Powell Page, and one brother, George H. Burwell, all of Clarke county.

document.text: Williamsburg, Va.,- Faced by the greatest turn-out of talent in the his tory of the seven-year-old produc tion, officials of The Common Glory announced today that the last of three preliminary auditions for the eighth season will be held at Lex ington on Saturday, March 20. The Lexington tryouts, which will cover all phases of the drama except dancing, will be conducted in the Troubadour Theatre of Washington and Lee University from 1 to 3 P. M. Dance auditions were completed last Saturday at Randolph - Macon Womans College, Lynchburg. Director Howard Scammon of the Paul Green drama reported today that he and other members of the productions staff were overwhelmed by applications at auditions for drama, choral and orchestral jobs at the University of Virginia last Sat urday.

document.text: William F. Randolph, Jr., May Die Of Injuries. Berryville Special.William F. Randolph, Jr., formerly of Clarke, now with the Bank of Richmond, at Richmond, was thrown in a hurdle race at the Clarke County horse and colt show and seriously If not fatal ly hurt. In endeavoring to take the third hurdle, just in front of the grand stand, Randolphs mount. True Boy, blundered and fell, throwing young Randolph completely over him. Randolph struck full upon his temple and was rendered uncon scious. He Is In a hosjfital and his condition Is regarded as precarious. In the light-weight hunter class R. M. Peach, of Upperville, riding Aristocrat, was thrown at a hurdle, his mount falling also. He escaped with a few bruises. In the qualified hunters class Edward B. Jacobs, rid ing No Name, fell with hts mount at the first hurdle. His horse fell upon and rolled over him, but Jacobs escaped unhurt and rode the class out.

document.text: Will Seek Tafts Aid W ith the re-election of Congress man J. Hampton Moore, of Philadel phia, as its president, and the selec tion of New London, Conn., as the meeting place for its convention next September, the Atlantic Deeper W aterways Association finished the business sessions oLlts fourth annual convention here Thursday. A resolution was adopted appoint ing a committee of ten members to urge upon President T aft and Con gress the enactm ent of legislation carrying into effect the recommen dations of the boards of engineers of the United States Army, for the ex tension and improvement of the intra- costal waterways system. Addresses to the convention were made by M. K. King, of Virginia Congressman John H. Small, of North Carolina Isham Randolph, ftf the Chicago Sanitary Commission Logan W. Page, director of public roads, and E. Dana Durand, director of the cen sus. An annual saving of approximately 400,000,000 by improvement oL the main roads in the United States so as to cut the cost of hauling in half , was advdeated by Logan W aller Page, di rector of the office of public roads in the Federal Department of Agricul ture. Mr. Page said that 20 per cent, of the highways carry 90 per cent of the traffic and that 440,000 miles should be improved to accommodate present highway needs. If th e principal highways were al ways passable for heavy-loaded ve hicles, he said, there would not be such, great variations in- rates and freight congestion, railroad and water way equipment could be employed to better advantage, freight handled more cheaply and the farm er enabled, to take advantage of m arket prices. Mr. Page said that many farthing communities import more agricultural products than they export, owing to bad highways. The address of E. Dana Durand, di rector of tbe census, turned on the dominant position maintained by the thirteen original States. Although their territory comprises only one-eighth of the United States area, he said, they contain two-fifths of the population and produce 53 per cent, of the total value of manufac tured products, 46 per cent, of the mineral products and 61 per cent, of the coal. Their exports are 58 per cent, of the countrys total and their imports are 79 per cent. Their railroad mileage is 23 per cent, of the total qf the country and th e ir- proportion of railroad freight and passenger traffic is much larger. The water-borne traffic of the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts, exclusive of foreign trade, amounts to 37 per cent, of the countrys water-borne traffic.

document.text: We have had some sales of real estate of late that attracted unusual attention. Thirty-four acres ol land near town, bought for farming pur poses and uot for speculation sold for 8,000, Quite 1,00 an acre for arming landi sound guod. And tiro Nursery Plant, of which at one time I had high hope, was sold on the 2nd having been dvided into lots and small farme. The mansion house with twenty acres ad join i,.g was firstsold and bought by Profes sor Lear, of the Normal faculty, for 6 ,000. Just what use he will make of it is not yet known though it bae been suggested that it might be converted into a home for nnmarrird male members of the faculty. An other suggestion that it may bo made a Country Club, though I am not satisfied that Farmvilic is yet big enough to support a venture like that. Lots wero then sold of varying sizes and this was followed by the sale of s nail farms. Tbs sale ag gregated something over 12,000 and the bank authorities are pleased with rosults. It may be that the many owners ot the property will do moro for this section than the one, though 1 til reg.et the failure oi the nursery. Tne owner of the nursery piant, or the  etenubl owner, cuue to ns without money and each ventures require money to make the mare -go. A local branch of the Randolph 11 scon Alumni was organized here recently wRü 8. P. Luke as presi dent, J. M. Crute vice president B. H. Paulette, secretary and A. B. Armstrong treasurer. V. Hatcher met with the body and of coarse gave inspiration to the occasion. 1 witnessed the death of the dis pensary and never looked upon just each scene before. Orowds flocked to the place as bees about a hive And they continued to flock nntil the sun went down when the doors closed and dispensary days in Farm ville ended. Beceipts daring the day were some thing over thirteen hundred dollars. An l then another erowd gathered on Monday morning when it was known that the booze on hand would be given away. Pints and half pints lew thick- and fast and for four hours tne fun wax ed warm. Not being exposed to nahe bite I failed to call for mi A friend of mine, however, c-Jioil hie home in a buggy. D if Farm viile after twelve yeajtvof dispen sary life. Beceipk to the towi were large and sorfe day I will ge the total tu gratify my own onriosi ty and perhaps jurat of others. The king is deadlT ong live the king! The Bklckstone soldiers spent a week amh ns and left behind pleas ant memory. Fine lot of young  fellows manly in bearing and care ful of conduct. If war does couie, and God forbid, sue i soldier may be relied on for faithful and feai- lesB service. A little rain jnst now would be rich in blessing. My friend Mr. W. H. Richardson has the habit of taking just one mint julep a year and on Wednes day, the 3rd, the good wife made the annual delight and ai he drank smacked hie lips and said it was fine. A good prohibition friend by the way was invited to join him in the annual feast but asked that his julep be made stronger than that of the host, O, consistency thon an. a jewel. I read the Leader, the new local paper for Faripvillo, regularly and with interest re I always find in it local news of interest to me. Strange that any man wt o lovss hit- neighbors is wiiling to deny han sels the privilege and may I not adii the pleasure? of reading the local paper. And he should read hi- own paper and not that of his neigh bor. When a Normal girl comes down town without permission she is pun ished by being confined to the -cam- pas for a week. And the imprison ment is irksome. With a dozen owners of small farms near town we are going to learn all boat diversified and in tensified farming. Five acres would be reckoned a large farm in some countries and it remains to be seen what we of Sonthside Virginia will do with them. Dr. Paxton, pastor ot first Pres byterian church, Lynchburg, will be one of the speakers at the approach ing Hampden Sidney commence ment and a rich treat is in store for those who are privileged to hear him. A father went from Farm grille to Hopewell to see his two boys and spent half day finding them. Fjnt took bis stand at the postoffioe

document.text: Watermelons opened at 50 cents apiece, goon dropped to 10 and it looks now as though the bottom would drop out. Canteloupes have not been so in evidence and grapes received a severe shock from the early frost while the local peach crop has been a wide spread fail ure. Some newspaper scribbler wus silly enough to attack the health record of Farmvil le, and never was greater injustice done a place and people. I called but yesterday on a family recently come from Kan sas to make their home with us, and the good wife of the household remarked that she came to Virginia, Southside Virginia, in seaich of health and that she had found it. She had suffered for years from a distressing case of nasal catarrh, which had broken in upon the rest of night ar.d the comfort of day. The old enemy had been vanquish ed and she now enjoys the inesti mable blessings of good health, and all this in a community which scribbler describes as a pest hole. Strange that a man who started out to write falsely should have been bold enough to fly in the face of facts so well established. Now and then the cry sounds out from our jail for the jailor and on repairing to the place Mr. Bliss finds that the prisoners are fighting among themselves. Human punish ment as a corrective is a dead fail ure. The ruling passion losef none of its force behind prison bars. Our lithia water requires no ice anil so is the most economical of summer drinks. Judge Watkins made an irnpres sive speech before the Board of Su pervisors on last Saturday in the interest of our public school system Some of our good people dont yet understand that education costs something, that is that it should cost them something. A farmer in town the other day said his crops were never so good and that he had not had a drop too much of rain. Some farmers never have too much or too little. Prof. Thornton has decided not to accept the position offered him in the University of West Virginia. Miss Snow, of the Normal Facul ty, is the first to return for the work of another session. It looks like yesterday when vacation began. Tiire flies and sessions and vaca- cations fly with it. Some of our merchants are busy taking inventory. All of them have done well during the dull mouths of summer. The extra passenger traiu of the Tidewater  Western is being well patronized. Our people are complainiug of the injury done to the public roads of ihe county by the saw mill ua gone. At a recent meeting of the Board of Supervisors for Priice Edward, a license of 3 was placed on such vehicles. Scraping dirt to the middle of the road beds is a positive nuisance and ought to be prohibited by law. It simply means one prolonged and intensified mud- hole. There are so many premium ba bies in town that a baby show is in order, but woe to the rash mortals who conseut to serve as judges. An officer of a Confederate regi ment during the closing days of the war, called on the late Col. K. A Booker, who was then in charge of the Randolph House, for the use of a horse and left a valuable gold watch as security for its return. The hone was never returned and a daughter of Col. Booker still wears the watch. Within the recent past a letter has been received at the Herald office from a citizen of South Carolina m iking inquiries of the watch. The silence stretching over a period of more than 40 years is more than remarkable. Speaking of war incidents reminds me that Gen. Lee, on the retreat to Appo mattox, s p e n t a n i g h t at the Randolph Home, aud the night following Gen. Graut occupied the same apntmeuts, and the story goes that Gen. Lee left his tooth bru h and that Gen. Grant took possession of it History doesnt say that it was surrendered at Ap pomattox. Work on the new Methodist church is now well under way It will be the handsomest churi h building in Southside Virginia. Sheriff Dickuson went to North P to 1 na to blips lmck another ne-

document.text: Washington.In two weeks one ot the most interesting events scheduled tor this season will take place, and that is the wedding of the second daughter of the President of the United States. Miss Jessie Wilson will when she becomes the bride of Mr. Frances Bowen Sayre make the thirteenth bride to have been married in the White House. From now on specula tion will he rife as to the gifts, the trousseau, the Met of wedding guests, ana the thousand and one things that concern the young woman, Who fol lows bravely in her fathers footsteps and says Well, thirteen always was my lucky number. Mr. ayre, who is to share with Miss Wilson all the agreeable publicity of v White House wedding, probably cares as little as she that the wedding will be the thirteenth to be celebrated in the romantic old, colonial mansion, dear ito all Americans, and known to all familiarly, as the White Hbuse, in stead of the more stately and1 perhaps dignified name of the Executive Man sion. In itself it Is a romantic old mansion, it even hss a ghost or sev eral, according to the old time colored folk, who claim to have seen the haunts under the big front portico. But if there is a spook, it must be a benefloient old soul, for from this house of dreams the way to happiness has led for at least 12 other couples. A White House wedding ts an event to stir ones blood In Washington. When Miss Alice Roosevelt became the bride of Representative Nicholas Longworth In 1906 pages and pages were written concerning the event for days and even weeks before. It seem ed to be almost the only topic of news of interest to the people. And why should it not be, the White House be ing the house of the people, and its occupants put there by the people? An Historic List. The wedding of Miss Wilson and M t . Sayre, will be the last up to date of a long list of historic weddings which have since 1811 taken place in the White House. The first was that ot Lucy Payne Washington, sister of Mrs. James Madison, the wife of the then President Madison, who was married to D. Judge1 Todd, of Ken tucky. The others who have pledged their troth in the famous old mansion are In 1812, Anna Todd, cousin of Mrs. Madison, who married Representative John G. Jackson, of Virginia. In 1826, John Adams, son of Presi dent Adams, married his cousin, Helen Jackson. . From 1829 to 1837, during the Jack- son administration, there were three weddings. Della Lewis, a friend of President Jacksons, was married to Alphonse Joseph Yver Pageot, an at tache of the French Legation. Mary Easton, niece of President Jackson, was married to Ludem B. Polk, and Emily Martin, a connection of the Jackson family, was married to Lewis Randolph. In 1878, Emily Pratt, niece of Presi dent Hayes, and Gen. Russell Hastings were married. In 1886, President Cleveland and Frances Folsom were married. The daughters of Presidents who have married from the White House were Maria Monroe, who married her cousin, Samuel Gouveneur Elizabeth Tyler, who married William Waller NeWe Grant, who married Algernon Sartoris, and Alice Roosevelt, who married Nicholas Longsworth. Miss Wilson will be the fifth daughter of a president to be married in the White House.

document.text: Washington, D. C., May 8.The wedding of Miss Eleanor Randolph Wilson, youngest daughter of Presi dent Wilson, and William Glbba Mc Adoo, secretary of the treasury, took place Thursday at six oclock p. m., In the blue room of the White House. The wedding procession proceeded from the main stairway Into the cor ridor, through the north door of the bine room, to the platform erected In the south bay window of the room. Miss Sallle MoAdoo led the proces sion, followed by Mrs. Sayre and Miss Margaret Wilson. Miss Nancy Lana directly preceded the bride, who was escorted by the president The groom, with Dr. Cary Travers Grayson, met the wedding party at the altar. Mr McAdoo wore evening clothes and Dr. Grayson wore his uniform. Rev. Syl vester W. Bosch performed the cere mony. After the ceremony the wedding party proceeded to the red room, where they received congratulations and good wishes of the. company. The Marine band furnished the music. Supper was served at small tables In the state dining room. The decora tions of the bine room were lilies and ferns, and the decorations in the din ing-room were pink and white roses. Handsome Wedding Presents. In spite of the small list of invited guests the wedding presents were nu merous. Prominent among them were the beautiful silver tea service, given by the members of the house of rep resentatives, a piece of Jewelry from members of the senate, twelve silver plates and a platter from the cabinet members and their wives, and a hand some gift from the Justices of the Su premo court. From the diplomatic corpe, no member of which was In vited, came flowers and good wishes. The brides bouquet was of orange blossoms, white orchids and lilies of the valley. The flower girls carried white chip hats, hung by ribbons, filled with flowers. Mias Margaret Wilsons gown was of soft blue crape with panniers and waist of bine tulle. The neck was finished with a cream lace ruff and a flowered sash completed the costume. With this costume was worn a blue lace hat, trimmed with pink roses and touches of black. Mrs. Sayres cos tume was exactly like Mlse Wilsons except that the color was pink. The gowns of the little flower girls were white, with blue and pink ribbons. Beautiful Wedding Gown. Tho wedding gown worn by Miss Wilson is made of ivory-white satin and trimmed with real old point lace. The bodice is softly draped with satin, which crosses in front and is brought to a point below the shoulders, front and back. The V-shaped neck is fin ished with folds of soft tulle. The long mousquetalre sleeves are made

document.text: WASHINGTON.  Americans who took Manila from the Spaniards in 1898 are proud of MacArthurs march, but they recall with pride some of their own achievements in taking the Philippines. First-hand accounts are heavy with heroics, says the Associated Press. Marine Sgt. William Vogt, who pried Spanish shrapnel out of the rigging inches from where Comdr. George Dewey stood and made him self some cuff buttons, recalls We arrived off Luzon on April 30 sighted the Spaniard and right away went in, ignoring rumors of torpedoes. We stood down in col umn at 400-yard intervals and opened fire at 5,000 yards, closing in to 2,000. Deweys old tubs consisted of four protected cruisers, including the flagship Olympia one unprotected cruiser, one gunboat and one armed revenue cutter. Spanish Admiral Montojo had a museum piece battleship, one old wooden steamer which had to be towed, two protected cruisers and three gunboats. Montojo lost 165 killed and 214 wounded out of 1,875 men. One of Deweys deck hands dropped dead  from excitement, and 7 of his 1,748 j men were slightly wounded. Dewey, however, was leery of ceived word last week that their , Spains one modern battleship, said son, Randolph, was made a sc goant at Camp Wheeler, Ga. Donald Roach night with B. T. spent Saturday Almond. Mr. and Mrs. G T Marsh spent Friday night with her sister, Mrs. Floyd Wooldridge, who continues veiy iil.

Suffice to say, it was here that Alice Hudson Cheatham Babcock had her start and her intervening fifty years have been spent in a school room. After her graduation from Appomattox High School and Randolph - Macon Womans College in Lynchburg, she took post-graduate work at Colum bia University in New York. She now holds a B. A. and M. A. degree and is assistant principal in one of Columbia, S. C. high schools. At a called meeting of the South- side District School Board held at Appomattox C. H. on August 19 1907, J. C. Jones resigned as clerk and J. R. Hamilton was elected in his place. It is to the late Mr. Hamil ton that we owe our records and most all our information on the early Evergreen school. document.text: Walton Hamlett Pillow, 78, an Appomattox County farmer, died Friday, August 10, at Memorial Hospital, Lynchburg. Born near Brookneal, Campbell County, he was the son of the late John William and Arnette Driskill Pillow. He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Lillie Lee Pillow six sons, Herbert W., of Lynchburg Her man O., of Blackstone Johnnie W., of Norfolk tfflger L., of Spout Spring Harold F., of Madison Heights, and Wise E., U. S. Navy three daughters, Mrs. Keturah Bowles, of Newport News Mrs. Jessie W. Griffin,  of Lynchburg, and Mrs. Charles M. Rush, of Ap pomattox two, brothers, Leonard Pillow, of Brbokneal, and Charlie L. Pillow, of Lynchburg two sis ters, Mrs. Frank Carwile and Mr 9 . George Ramsey, of Brookneal 13 grandchildren and 14 great grand children. Funeral services were held Sum- day at 330 P. M. from Providence Baptist Church. The services were conducted by the Rev. L. P. Brown, assisted by the Rev. Randolph Hite, the Rev. S. A. Dean, and the Rev. Irvin A. Orndoff. Interment was in Falling River Baptist Church Cem- etary, Brookneal.

CHAPTER 31. Accident and Casualty Reporting. R31-3. In addition to the notification required by R31-2, the operator of a vessel shall submit a written casualty or accident report to the Commis sion when, as a result of an occurence that involved the vessel or its equipment  1  a person dies  2  a person is unable to perform normal or usual activities 3 damage to the vessel and other property damage totals more than two hundred dollars or 4 a person dissapears from the vessel under circumstances that indi cate probable death or injury. A written report required by this regulation must be made I  1  within forty-eight hours of  the occurence if a person dies within twenty-four hours of the ojcriu-ence  2  within forty- 6 f th 8 if a person is unable to perform normal or usual activities or disappears from a vessel and  3  within ten days of the occurrence or death if an earlier report is not required by the foregoing provisions of this regulation. document.text: W. M. Thompson Sr. William M. Thompson, Sr., 64, of 6910 Horsepen rd., died Sun day. A copy editor a n d former make-up editor for The Rich mond News Leader, he was graduated from Randolph - Macon College, where he was a member of Phi Delta Theta fraternity. He had been on The News Leader Staff for 20 years. He is survived by his wife, Mrs. Virgilia Atwood Thompson a son, William M. Thompson, Jr., of Portsmouth and a sister, Miss Mary O. Thompson, of Kingsport, Tenn. A funeral service was held at 10 a.m. Tuesday at Joseph W. Bliley Funeral Home, with bur ial at 2 p.m. in Springhill Ceme tery, Lynchburg. Mr. Thompson was the son of the late Dr. and Mrs. William Edgar Thompson, a Methodist minister.

In the kindergarten through grade 2 category, first-place winner was Thomas Nolen, second-place winner was Hea ther Martin, third-place winner was Nicole Randolph, and the work of Daphne Jackson and LaTasha Johnson, received honorable mention. In the grade 3 through 5 category, first place went to Mike Whitmer, second place went to Sarah Mitchell, third place to Rodney Thompson, and Angie Thompson and Joe Servis received honorable mention. In the grades 6 through 8 Category, first place went to Cheryl Wooten, second place went to Angie Whitmer, third place went to John Ackerman, and honorable mention went to Paul Sheen and Debbie Hail. In the grades 9 through 12 category first place went to Bruce McClary, second dace went to Teresa Mayberry, third place went to Ron Carter, and honorable mention, went to Rosa , Harvey and- Randy Phelps. , Judges for the event were Jennifer Midgett, Wendy Ric hardson, Emily Burke, and Susan Weatherly. First-place winners received a 25 passbook savings account from American Federal Sav ings and Loan, second-place winners received a 15 pass book, third place winners received a 10 passbook, and those receiving honorable men tion received a 5 passbook. document.text: Virginias leading beef cattle producers will meet at VPI March -0 for three days of discussions arid laboratory sessions covering practically every phase of the beef cactle business. The course, second of its  kind in Virginia, is sponsored jointly by thj animal husbandry department at VtT, the Virginia Beef Cattle Producers Association, and the state breed associations. The first day will be devoted to problems of feeding. George Litton, haed of the animal husbandry de partment will lead off with the fun damentals of good feeding. Jack Copenhaver, in charge of the col lege herds, will discuss feeding the breeding herd the year round. A prominent Virginia Angus breeder, B. A. Rucker, of Albemarle, wil. discuss feeding of show cattle. Pro fessor R. E. Hunt, VPI, will trace the history and trends in Virginias beef cattle business and Allan Randolph, Keene, secretary of the State Association,will diseuss Eth ics in thé Cattle Business. The town of Vinton was thrown into a state of great excitement over the ar rest of a negro named Early Ferguson, charged with assaulting Luella Thomas, a 13-year-old girl, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. C. Thomas. The assault oc curred near Bonsack. The authorities gave the negro a preliminary hearing and owing to the state of feeling he was hurried to the Salem jail for safe keep ing. There would doubtless have been a lynching if he had been kept at Vinton over night. Fergusons reputation is unsavory, he having just completed an eight months sentence for an attempted assault on Fay M organ, aged 11 years, about a year ago. Stanley Hinton, colored, 30 years old. fireman at the Smithfield Ice Company s plant in Smithfield, met a horrible death. His neck and one arm were broken and his skull was crushed by the startng of the big driving wheel, between the spokes of which he had thrust his head while he was looking after machinery. One of the plants owners said that the creation of a vacuum caused the wheel to make a partial revolution. Champe Braxton Shepherd, a son of Joseph H. Shepherd, until recently a clerk in the office of the Auditor of Pub lic Accounts of Virginia, was picked up on the streets of Chicago a mental wreck and sent to Kankakee Asylum. L ong rest and treatment, it is thought, may restore him. Young Shepherd served with honor in the Philippine Islands and was on his way to his old home in Richmond when attacked. Officer J. H. Madison, brother of the Delegate from Newport district, put two bullets into Henry Hall, a Norfolk negro whom lie was trying to arrest on the steamer Belle Norton. The negro, who will probably die, had wrenched the club ftom the officers hand and split his head open before he could draw his revolver. Three bystanders, who refused to assist the policeman, were arrested and fined. Mr. Frederick Berry and Miss Lucy Conner, both of Stafford County, were married at the Baptist parsonage near Leeland, Rev. T. T. Lynn officiating. Leroy S. Edwards, principal of the Springfield School at Richmond, and son of Rev. John E. Edwards, died after a long illness. The suit of Brightwell vs. Pulliam, in volving the Randolph gold mine prop erty, which has been pending since 1851, has been finally settled in the Circuit Court at Fredericksburg and a decree has been entered ordering the sale of the property. Every lawyer and judge who was first connected with this case is dead. The Rockingham Horse and Colt Show Association has purchased and handsomely equipped new grounds within the town of Harrisonburg.includ- ing a fine race track. The association is to hold its first show on August 28 and 29. Liberal premiums are offered. In Orange county at the home of the bride Mr. Charles Adams and Miss Flor ence Burch were united in marriage by Rev. Mr. Harlow. Miss Julia Mann was maid of honor and Mr. John Adams best man. Extensive improvements arc to lie made at Westover, once owned by W il liam Byrd, founder of Richmond, and recently purchased by Mrs. W . M. Ram  sey, of California. The mansion will he remodeled, but will not be changed in architectural appearance. Floyd and Grayson counties have vot ed an appropriation of 150.000 for build ing the Marion and Rye Valley railroad. A lumber deal in Smytlie and Grayson counties involves 17,000 acres, at a cot of 103,000 to Pennsylvania capitalists. Stearne Fosque, the negro under sen tence of death in Accomac for murder, escaped from the jail there. The Gov ernor had refused to commute the mans sentence to life imprisonment. Robert A. Bibb, a popular conductor on the Virginia and Southwestern Rail way. fell between the cars of his train at Bluff City and was crushed to death. He ayas 45 years of age, and is survived by his widow and four children. T. J. Chambers, general grocer, ol Fredericksburg, has made a voluntary assignment for the benefit of creditors 38 in number, some of whom are Balti more and Richmond firms. Liabi i i.-s abont Iro.ooo assets unknown. During a severe electrical storm ir Warrenton the art studio of Mr. Rich ard N. Brooke avas struck by Fgh nine and set on fire. Prompt attention save it. The damage is small. W . L. Davis planing mill and blind sash and door factory and the boltlinf establishment of the Home Brewing Company, on Lombard street. Peters burg, were destroyed by fire. Total Ibis 18,000 insurance, 6oco. Mr. Robert H. Payne and Miss Carra M. Nottingham were married in Cul peper county at the home of the bride parents, Rev. Carter Page officiating. The Clarke County Colt and Horsi Show Association, which was recently organized, will hold its first annua meeting September 4 and 5 at it grounds near Berryville. Rev. C. C. Edington. a Methodis Episcopal preacher and former presidinj elder at El Paso, Texas, died at his liomi in Ballahack of consumption.

document.text: Virginia Daughters Meet. The eighteenth annual convention of the Virginia division, United Daugh ters of the Confederacy, was held here. Nearly 500 delegatee assembled at the City Auditorium and were welcomed by Lléot.-Gov. J. Taylor EUyeon, Act ing Mayor W. H. Adams and Mrs. N. V. Randolph for -the Richmond chap ter. A feature of the session was the presentation by the Daughters of a beautiful flag to toe First Virginia Regiment in -memory of its members who died in battle. The presentation speech was made by Mrs. A. A. Camp bell, of Wy-theville, president of the Virginia division, United Daughters of the Confederacy. Major L. T. Price received the flag in behalf of the regi ment. The Daughters of the Con federacy, unanimously passed resolu tions Indorsing those passed at a re cent meeting of the Stonewall Jackson monument corporation, which provide that the Governors of Virginia and the other Southern States be requested to set apart January 21, 1914, as flag day for the Stonewall Jackson monument corporation. The Virginia Daughters are enthusiastic In the work of raising funds tor a monument to Stonewall Jackson and the work of Interesting other State divls-lons will go forward. The report of Mrs. S. A. Riddick, treas urer, showed receipts for the year ol 1,561.69 disbursements, 775.17 bal ance on hand, 776.52. The convention approved a movement, headed by Mrs. N. V. Randolph, to have a State wom ans college erected near the Uni versity of Virginia. The proposition will be presented to the State Legisla ture in January.

document.text: Very Good F or New York, B u t Chicago Takes the Palm . By the way, said the drummer as he took a cigar out of his case and reached for a match, this American nation has lost heaps of money by not knowing a good thing when it was crawling abound in the grass. To what do you refer ? asked the man who had been sharpening his knife on his bootleg. To this cigar case. Latest fad outmade of snakeskin and com bines beauty and wear. We might mve been using that sort of material for the last 200 years, bnt didnt know a good thing. Are yon sure its snakeskin ? Of course. Havent you been in New York lately? No. Place on Gland street where they make em while you ait. Not only that, but you can piok out your own snake. The day I went in they had abont 50 of them in a cage, and I was told to seleot the one I fancied most. I made my choice, and he was taken out, his skin slipped off, and in about 20 minutes I had this Case. Very convenient dont you know, and its a strictly New York idea.  I think we can beat it in Chicago, however, said the other man as he changed his knife to the other boot- leg Anything new there ? You bet I Theres a restaurant on State street where they serve oxtail soup at 10 cents a plate, and they bring in the ox and cat his tail off right before yonr eyes. In that way there can be no deception. They use aliont 1,500 tails per day. ! Must make a big lot of bobtailed oxen out yonr way ? Oh, it does.  And a bobtailed ox is not a thing of beauty. By no means, not until he is fixed. How fixed? Why, as fast- as they leave the restaurant they are taken over to a place on Randolph street and de horned. And then ? And then they are sent east and sold as Jersey cows. Yon get yonr sonp, your horns, yonr fad and yonr Jersey cow. All verysimple and very convenient, yon know, and iff strictly a Chicago idea!  The man with the snakeskin oigar case sat and thought for a while with a very serions expression of counte nance and then suddenly said Ive tried and tried, but its no use, and I might as well give it up. Whats that? Lying! The other fallow is al ways from Chicago and always heats me out of sight!Detroit Free Press.

document.text: VERY DESPONDENT. Mr. Marshall had of late years been very despondent. This was due to unsuccessful business ven tures and family afflictions. In 1880 one of his sons, Albert, shot and killed Mmself, Ms act having, it is supposed, been caused by a love affair. About three years ago an other son, James, fell from a horse in Florida and was killed. Mr. Marshall was fifty-eight years of age, was a man of very quiet de meanor and strictly temperate. He leaves a wife and five children, Col onel Thomas R. Marshall, command ant of cadets at the Virginia Mili tary Institute Messrs. William P., Randolph, Robert and Miss Sally Marshall. Mrs. Marshall was in Lexington at the time of her husbands death visiting her son, Colonel Marshall. She was telegraphed for and with Colonel Marshall arrived here Friday Mght.
